description: From Latin fulminātus, past participle of fulminō (“lighten, hurl or strike with lightning”), from fulmen (“lightning which strikes and sets on fire, thunderbolt”), from earlier *fulgmen, *fulgimen, from fulgeō, fulgō (“flash, lighten”). Doublet of fulmine. More at fulgent.

entries.meaning: (chemistry) Any salt or ester of fulminic acid, mostly explosive.
examples: On 19 February a jubilant Bigeard announced that his 3rd R.P.C. had seized eighty-seven bombs, seventy kilos of explosive, 5,120 fulminate of mercury detonators, 309 electric detonators, etc.

verbs.description: fulminate (third-person singular simple present fulminates, present participle fulminating, simple past and past participle fulminated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively) To make a verbal attack.
(transitive, figuratively) To issue as a denunciation.
examples: They fulminated the most hostile of all decrees.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To thunder or make a loud noise.
(transitive, now rare) To strike with lightning; to cause to explode.
examples: the present owners couldn't afford the electric bills anymore, several amateur gaffers, sad to say, having already been fulminated trying to bootleg power in off the municipal lines.
